com.edugility.liquiunit
Class H2Rule

java.lang.Object
  org.junit.rules.ExternalResource
      com.edugility.liquiunit.H2Rule
All Implemented Interfaces:
Wrapper, CommonDataSource, DataSource, TestRule
public class H2Rule
extends ExternalResource
implements DataSource

An ExternalResource that is also a DataSource for in-memory H2 Connections, with some additional special characteristics suited particularly for thread-safe, parallel in-memory unit testing.

As with all ExternalResources, this class is not safe for use by multiple concurrent threads.

Instances of this class are often passed to new LiquiunitRule instances.

Author:
Laird Nelson
See Also:
ExternalResource, DataSource, the H2 database website

getJPAProperties

public Map<?,?> getJPAProperties()

apply

public Statement apply(Statement base,
                       Description description)
Overrides the ExternalResource.apply(Statement, Description) method to store the supplied Description for usage by the getConnection(String, String) method internally and returns the superclass' return value.

It must be assumed that this method may return null since the superclass documentation does not mention whether the return value must be non-null.

Specified by:
apply in interface TestRule
Overrides:
apply in class ExternalResource
Parameters:
base - the Statement to decorate; the superclass documentation does not define what behavior will occur if this parameter is null
description - the Description describing the test underway; the superclass documentation does not define what behavior will occur if this parameter is null
Returns:
a Statement; possibly null
See Also:
getConnection(String, String), ExternalResource.apply(Statement, Description)

before

protected void before()
               throws SQLException
Opens a new Connection to a thread-private H2 in-memory database and restores any state that was stored by the after() method.

Overrides:

Specified by:

Returns:

Throws:

getConnection

public Connection getConnection(String username,
                                String password)
                         throws SQLException
Internally uses the DriverManager.getConnection(String, String, String) method to create a Connection to a new, in-memory H2 database that is safe for use by the current Thread, not just the current JVM.

In-memory H2 databases by default are private to a given Connection. For most unit- and integration-testing purposes, that is not sufficient, as often several Connections have to be opened to those databases to perform various operations. What you want is a way to have two independently created Connections connect to the same in-memory H2 database instance.

This is easy to do, of course—you simply name the database (e.g. jdbc:h2:mem:fred instead of just jdbc:h2:mem:). But you want to isolate this name from other threads and processes that might try to connect to it, so you need to pick a name that is unique to the current Thread. This method accomplishes just such a Connection.

The JDBC URL that is used to open a Connection is built according to the following template:

jdbc:h2:mem:[TEST_NAME-]pid=PID-thread=THREAD_ID[;INIT=INIT_SQL]

...where brackets denote optional elements, TEST_NAME is the return value of the Description.getDisplayName() method, PID is the return value of the pid() method, THREAD_ID is the return value of the Thread.getId() method when invoked on the current Thread and INIT_SQL is the initialization SQL passed to the constructor.

The Connection returned is guaranteed to be non-null and not closed.

Specified by:
getConnection in interface DataSource
Parameters:
username - the username to use; may be null
password - the password to use; may be null
Returns:
a non-null open Connection
Throws:
SQLException - if an error occurs
See Also:
DriverManager.getConnection(String, String, String), DriverManager.getConnection(String), The section on in-memory databases in the H2 documentation

pid

public String pid()
Returns the current process identifier as a String.

This method may return null in exceptional circumstances.

The default implementation returns a String resulting from the following invocation:

java.lang.management.ManagementFactory.getRuntimeMXBean().getName().substring(0, name.indexOf('@'));

Returns:
the current process identifier as a String, or null
See Also:
ManagementFactory, RuntimeMXBean
